{{Infobox person | name = Manny Mashouf | image = Manny Mashouf-02-13-08.jpg | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1938|7|6|df=y}}
| birth_place = [[Tehran]], [[Iran]] | nationality = [[Iranian peoples|Iranian]], [[Americans|American]] | other_names = | years_active = | known_for = Founding [[Bebe Stores]] | residence = | occupation = Chairman, [[Bebe stores]] | spouse = | children = | website = | networth = [[United States dollar|US$]]1.3 [[1,000,000,000 (number)|billion]] (2007)<ref name="networth">{{cite web| title = The World's Billionaires #754 Manny Mashouf & family| publisher = [[Forbes]]| date = 2007-08-03| url = https://www.forbes.com/lists/2007/10/07billionaires_Manny-Mashouf-family_CFHU.html| accessdate = 2007-08-03 }}</ref> | Spouse = Neda Mashouf (Divorced) }} '''Manny Mashouf''' (born 6 July 1938) is an [[Iranian-American]] businessman and philanthropist known for founding [[Bebe Stores]].
==Early life and education== Born in [[Iran]] in 1938, he came to the [[United States]] in his teens and settled first in [[Washington D.C.]], then in [[San Francisco]]. There, he went to [[San Francisco State University]] and graduated with a [[political science]] degree. He first managed a steakhouse, before founding his own fashion line.<ref>{{cite web|title=Manny Mashouf |url=http://iranians.kodoom.com/en/manny-mashouf/ |publisher=iranians.kodoom.com/en |accessdate=22 November 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161123054943/http://iranians.kodoom.com/en/manny-mashouf/ |archivedate=23 November 2016 |df= }}{{dead link|date=April 2017}}</ref>
==Career== He was the manager and chairman of [[Bebe stores]]. In 1998, he took the company public.<ref name=former-richest>{{Citation |last= |first= |year=2006 |title=#242 Manny Mashouf & family |publisher=''[[Forbes]]'' |publication-place= |page= |url=https://www.forbes.com/lists/2006/54/biz_06rich400_Manny-Mashouf-family_CFHU.html |accessdate=April 23, 2017 }}</ref>
In 2006 Mashouf was worth US$1.5 billion - resulting in Forbes listing him as the 242nd richest American.<ref name=former-richest/> By 2007 that has dropped to $1.3 Billion.<ref name="networth">{{cite web| title = The World's Billionaires #754 Manny Mashouf & family| publisher = [[Forbes]]| date = 2007-08-03| url = https://www.forbes.com/lists/2007/10/07billionaires_Manny-Mashouf-family_CFHU.html| accessdate = 2007-08-03 }}</ref>
Partnered with Giovanni Agnelli and Manny Mashouf, [[Scott Bloom]] founded the production company [[Argonaut Pictures]] in 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117991716.html?categoryid%3D3235%26cs%3D1 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-11-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080915070423/http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117991716.html?categoryid=3235&cs=1 |archivedate=2008-09-15 |df= }}</ref>
It was announced in 2015 that he was to sell his 59% stake in Bebe.<ref name=sell-stake>{{Citation |last= |first= |year=2015 |title=Bebe Founder Manny Mashouf Sells 59 Percent Stake |publisher=ubmfashion.com |publication-place= |page= |url=http://www.ubmfashion.com/blogs/bebe-founder-manny-mashouf-sell-59-stake |accessdate= }}{{dead link|date=April 2017}}</ref>
All of Bebe's stores are scheduled to close and liquidate inventory by the end of May 2017.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-03-21/bebe-said-to-plan-to-shut-its-stores-in-brick-and-mortar-retreat |title=Bebe Plans to Shut Its Stores and Focus on Web Sales |date=21 March 2017 |website=bloomberg.com}}</ref>
==Philanthropy== In 2005 Mashouf pledged $10 million to his [[alma mater]], San Francisco State for a performing arts center.<ref name=philantrhopy-nedia/> The donation was later redirected to the construction of the Mashouf Wellness Center.<ref name=sf-examiner>{{cite news |last=Barba |first=Michael |date= April 22, 2017 |title=Founder of Closing Bebe Stores had Philanthropic Ties to State |url=http://www.sfexaminer.com/founder-closing-bebe-stores-philanthropic-ties-sf-state/ | work=[[San Francisco Examiner]] |location= |access-date=April 24, 2017}}</ref>
==Personal life== As of 2005, he was married to Neda Mashouf.<ref name=philantrhopy-nedia>{{Citation |last= |first= |date= June 7, 2005|title=San Francisco State Receives $10 Million for New Arts Center |publisher=Philanthropy News Digest |publication-place= |page= |url=http://philanthropynewsdigest.org/news/san-francisco-state-receives-10-million-for-new-arts-center|accessdate=April 23, 2017 }}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of California State University, Fresno people]] *[[List of San Francisco State University people]] *[[List of fashion designers]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://www.forbes.com/lists/2006/54/biz_06rich400_Manny-Mashouf-family_CFHU.html Manny Mashouf] at [[Forbes.com]]
{{authority control}}

revision.text:
{{Other uses|Master contract (disambiguation){{!}}Master contract}} A '''master contract''' or '''master agreement''' is a [[collective bargaining]] agreement which covers all [[trade union|unionized]] worksites in an industry, market or company, and which establishes the terms and conditions of employment common to all workers in the industry, market or company.<ref name="Roberts">Najita, Joyce, and Roberts, Harold S. ''Roberts' Dictionary of Industrial Relations.'' Washington, D.C.: BNA Books, 1994. {{ISBN|0871797771}}</ref><ref name="LaborEducation">[http://labored.missouri.edu/Historic%20Models%20of%20Collective%20Bargaining%20in%20the%20U.S.htm Rainsberger, Paul K. "Historical Models of Collective Bargaining in the U.S." In "Collective Bargaining." University of Missouri Labor Education Program. No date.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080412220224/http://labored.missouri.edu/Historic%20Models%20of%20Collective%20Bargaining%20in%20the%20U.S.htm |date=2008-04-12 }} Accessed July 30, 2008.</ref><ref>''Korea Shipping Corporation v. New York Shipping Association-International Longshoremen's Association Pension Trust Fund,'' [[case citation|880 F.2d 1531]] (1989).</ref>
==About master contracts== A master contract may be geographically limited and occur at the local, regional or national level. It may also be limited to a specific market, whether local, regional or national.<ref>Hardin, Patrick; Higgins, Jr, John E.; Hexter, Christopher T.; and Neighbours, John T. ''The Developing Labor Law: The Board, the Courts, and the National Labor Relations Act.'' 4th ed. Washington, D.C.: BNA Books, 2002. {{ISBN|1-57018-151-9}}; Williams, Steve and Adam-Smith, Derek. ''Contemporary Employment Relations: A Critical Introduction.'' Oxford, England: Oxford University Press, 2005. {{ISBN|0-19-927243-3}}</ref> Although a master contract governs the general terms of employment that apply uniformly across the company or industry, master contracts often provide for local terms to be negotiated.<ref name="Roberts" /> Some master contracts may also permit local or regional variations in order to meet special economic, competitive, or other circumstances for a union or company.<ref name="Roberts" /> For example, in the early 1980s the [[United Auto Workers]] exempted [[Chrysler]] from the master contract governing the U.S. auto industry because the company was in deep financial trouble.<ref name="Levin">Levin, Doron P. "Chrysler Makes Plea To U.A.W." ''New York Times.'' July 21, 1990.</ref>
Master contracts are common in the automobile manufacturing, shipping, package express, mining (especially coal mining), and general manufacturing industries. For example, the UAW and the [[Big Three automobile manufacturers|"Big Three" American automakers]] tend to operate in this pattern: the union selects one manufacturer with which it does most of its negotiation; when an agreement is reached, the union attempts to apply the same contract to the others.<ref name="LaborEducation" /> Other areas where master agreements can be found include tire manufacturing,<ref>Brus, Brian. "Bridgestone/Firestone, Union Negotiators Reach Master Contract." ''Oklahoma City Journal Record.'' June 10, 2005.</ref> public education,<ref>Todd, Kris. "Spencer Teachers' 2008-09 Master Contract Ratified." ''Spencer Daily Report.'' May 9, 2008.</ref> baking,<ref>Cimini, Michael H. and Muhl, Charles J. "Master Contract at Philip Morris." ''Monthly Labor Review.'' May 1995.</ref> custodial and housekeeping services,<ref>Pryor, Alex. "OneSource, SEIU Union Reach Contract for Tufts Janitors." ''Tufts Daily.'' September 22, 2004.</ref> and healthcare.<ref>Rauber, Chris. "CHW Hospitals Deliver Union Contract After Short Labor." ''San Francisco Business Times.'' April 25, 1997.</ref>
In some cases, the goal of a master agreement is to standardize pay and benefit conditions in a market or industry so that employers compete on the grounds of quality services, quality products, or improved [[Occupational safety and health|workplace safety]].<ref>Brisbin Jr., Richard A. ''A Strike Like No Other Strike: Law and Resistance During the Pittston Coal Strike of 1989-1990.'' Baltimore, Md.: Johns Hopkins University Press, 2002. {{ISBN|0-8018-6901-3}}.</ref><ref name="Royle">Royle, Tony and Towers, Brian. ''Labour Relations in the Global Fast-food Industry.'' New York: Routledge, 2002. {{ISBN|0-415-22167-6}}</ref>
Master contracts also make it easier for newly organized workers, who get rolled into existing contract rather than having to negotiate their own first contract (with the risk that negotiations may drag on or collapse, causing the new union to eventually collapse).<ref name="Royle" />
[[Closed shop|Traditionally]], such contracts have been struck as exclusive class actions between the whole class of workers and the whole class of (or a single) employer(s), excluding the employment of any workers outside of it. In the [[Right to work state|United States]] in particular there has been pressure from the employing class generally on this.
==Strategy== When negotiating a master contract, the union often selects the financially strongest employer or worksite to negotiate with it. This agreement becomes the master contract, and [[pattern bargaining|sets the pattern]] for bargaining with the other employers or worksites.<ref name="Levin" /><ref>"USWA Names Goodyear Target for Master Contract Talks." ''Rubber & Plastics News.'' April 14, 2003; Freeman, Sholnn. "Union Picks GM to Lead Contract Talks." ''Washington Post.'' September 14, 2007.</ref>
Master contracts can also be used strategically for other ends such as organizing and to break down employer resistance to collective bargaining. In Canada, unions have used master contracts to organize thousands of new workers. A master agreement has tended to weaken an employer's resistance to the spread of the union to unorganized worksites or divisions, and some industries and markets welcome the standardization of pay and fringe benefits that unionization brings.<ref>Yates, Charlotte. "Expanding Labour's Horizons: Union Organizing and Strategic Change in Canada." ''Just Labour.'' 2002.</ref> In the United States, some unions have sought to create master agreements which provide for a neutrality agreement, code of conduct for the organizing election, or neutral third-party oversight of an election in order to make union organizing easier.<ref name="Kutalik">[http://www.labornotes.org/node/1054 Kutalik, Chris. "Two Unions Enter Recognition Pact with Health Care Company." ''Labor Notes. July 2003.]</ref> Some master agreements even state that new workers will automatically come under the master agreement.<ref name="Kutalik" /> Master bargaining also reduces the likelihood that employers will refuse to bargain or seek to whittle away at unionization workplace by workplace.<ref>Fairbrother, Peter and Yates, Charlotte. ''Trade Unions in Renewal: A Comparative Study.'' New York: Routledge, 2003. {{ISBN|0-8264-5437-2}}</ref>
==Criticisms== Some union members criticize master contracts for submerging local differences, and for being undemocratic.<ref>The claim is that by permitting thousands or even tens of thousands of members to vote on a contract, the master contract makes it impossible for the contract's opponents to muster enough votes across all workplaces to defeat the contract. For an example, see: [http://www.uniondemocracy.com/UDR/66-ILA%20dockers%20against%20contract.htm Biers, Carl and Niemeijer, Marsha. "Dockworkers Campaign Against ILA Master Agreement." ''Union Democracy Review.'' June–July 2004.]</ref> Many critics point to master contracts which impose certain fundamental terms and conditions of employment (such as wages, fringe benefits, pensions and certain working conditions) as being nothing more than [[company union]]ism.<ref name="Kutalik" /> In the United States, unions have engaged in bitter battles over such master agreements in California and Ohio.<ref>[http://labornotes.org/taxonomy/term/55?from=15 Gaus, Mischa. "Quiet Deal Leads to Bitter Fight in Ohio Hospitals." ''Labor Notes.'' April 2008]; [http://labornotes.org/node/1556 Brenner, Mark. "Health Care Local Charges SEIU Is Shutting Members Out of Bargaining & Organizing." ''Labor Notes.'' March 2008]; White, Ronald D. "Unions Battle for Nurses." ''Los Angeles Times.'' August 3, 2003; Lando, Tamar. "Union Triage." ''L.A. Weekly.'' September 25, 2003; Kaplan, Esther. "Labor's Growing Pains." ''The Nation.'' June 16, 2008.</ref>
In [[Australia]], master contracts proved so contentious that they were essentially outlawed under the 1996 [[WorkChoices]] legislation and its 2005 amendments.<ref>Murray, Jill. "Work Choices and the Radical Revision of the Public Realm of Australian Statutory Labour Law." ''Industrial Law Journal.'' December 2006.</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
{{Organized labor}}
[[Category:Labor relations]] [[Category:Collective rights]]

'''Michael Tsamaz''' ({{lang-el|Μιχάλης Τσαμάζ}}) has been the Chairman and CEO of the [[OTE|Hellenic Telecommunications Organization]] (OTE) since 3 November 2010.<ref name="Bloomberg Businessweek">{{cite news|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=26936972&ticker=HTO:GA&previousCapId=4997563&previousTitle=VIRGIN%20MEDIA%20INC |title=Hellenic Telecommunications Organization | publisher=Bloomberg Businessweek}}</ref>
He joined OTE Group in 2001 and became Head of [[Cosmote]] in 2007.<ref name="Hellenic Telecommunications Organization">{{cite news|url=https://www.ote.gr/web/guest/corporate/company/who-we-are/management/board-of-directors/details/-/asset_publisher/ZXK3cdQ6tyAp/content/michael-tsam-1 |title=Michael Tsamaz. | publisher=Hellenic Telecommunications Organization}}</ref>
In the year 2017 he announced the Group will prioritise the deployment of fibre optics networks, as part of an investment plan of 1.5 billion euros<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.liberal.gr/arthro/146628/oikonomia/epicheiriseis/m-tsamaz-anebainei-o-pichis-gia-to-2017--oi-treis-stratigikoi-stochoi-tou-ote.html|title=M. Tsamaz: Raising the bar for 2017 (in Greek)|last=|first=|date=21.06.17|website=Liberal|access-date=}}</ref> extending throughout 2020.
In 2011, he reached an agreement with the Federation of OTE Employees (ΟΜΕ-ΟΤΕ) to cut labour costs. The two sides agreed on an 11% cut in pay for the period 2012-2014, in return for the implementation of a 35-hour week and the preservation of job positions.<ref name="European Industrial Relations Observatory On-line">{{cite news|url=http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/eiro/2011/10/articles/gr1110019i.htm |title=OTE cuts costs in three-year deal with union | publisher=European Industrial Relations Observatory On-line|date=November 22, 2011}}</ref>
In September 2013, he announced investments of 1.2 billion euros to upgrade Greek fixed and mobile networks over the next four years having met with the Greek Prime Minister [[Antonis Samaras]].<ref name="Athens-Macedonian News Agency">{{cite news|url=http://www.amna.gr/english/articleview.php?id=3868 |title=PM Samaras briefed by OTE's CEO | publisher=Athens-Macedonian News Agency|date=September 25, 2013}}</ref>
He was listed no 44 Global Telecoms Business Power 100 for 2013.<ref name="Global Telecoms Business">{{cite news|url=http://www.globaltelecomsbusiness.com/Article/3259474/Global-Telecoms-Business-Power-100-for-2013.html |title=Global Telecoms Business Power 100 for 2013 | publisher=Global Telecoms Business|date=September 27, 2013}}</ref>
Michael Tsamaz was born in Athens in 1959<ref name="Form 20-F filed with the United States Securities and Exchange Commission">{{cite news |url=https://www.ote.gr/documents/10280/33302/twentyf10.pdf/4a78c7a7-cf25-4da2-ba92-cb5519e5671b |title=Hellenic Telecommunications Organization S.A. |publisher=Form 20-F filed with the United States Securities and Exchange Commission |date=June 17, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140815020654/https://www.ote.gr/documents/10280/33302/twentyf10.pdf/4a78c7a7-cf25-4da2-ba92-cb5519e5671b |archivedate=August 15, 2014 |df= }}</ref> and his family comes from [[Alasehir|Philadelphia]], [[Asia Minor]] and [[Chania]], [[Crete]].<ref name="Fortune Greece">{{cite news|url=http://www.fortunegreece.com/article/michalis-tsamaz-success-story-se-proto-prosopo/ |title=Michael Tsamaz in first-person | publisher=Fortune Greece |date=July 27, 2013 (in Greek)}}</ref> He holds a Bachelor’s Degree in Business Administration from the University of New Brunswick, Canada.<ref name="Deutsche Telekom">{{cite news|url=http://www.telekom.com/media/company/69182 |title=OTE: Michael Tsamaz new Chairman & CEO | publisher=Deutsche Telekom |date=October 22, 2010}}</ref>
==References==
<references />
{{DEFAULTSORT:Tsamaz, Micjael}} [[Category:Greek businesspeople]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1959 births]] [[Category:People from Athens]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use British English|date=August 2015}} '''Moulton Park''' is a large [[industrial estate]] near the village of [[Moulton, Northamptonshire]] a few miles north of the town of [[Northampton]].
==Business park== Nationwide Building Society have a main office on the business park, near to the [[BLC Leather Technology Centre]] (former British Leather Manufacturers' Research Association).
==Transmitter== The main transmitter for [[BBC Radio Northampton]] on 104.2FM is to the west of Moulton Park near the [[University of Northampton]] (former Nene College) on ''Boughton Green Road''. It also carries national FM radio.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{gbmapping|SP770647}} * [http://tx.mb21.co.uk/gallery/northampton.php Moulton Park transmitter]

Center |settlement_type = [[Business district]] of [[Newport Beach, California|Newport Beach]] |other_name = |native_name = <!-- for cities whose native name is not in English --> |nickname = |motto = |image_skyline = Fashion island Newport Beach CA Photo D Ramey Logan.jpg |imagesize = |image_caption = Newport Center Drive |image_flag = |flag_size = |image_seal = |seal_size = |image_shield = |established_date2 = |established_title3 = |established_date3 = |area_magnitude = |area_total_km2 = |area_total_sq_mi = |area_land_km2 = |area_land_sq_mi = |area_water_km2 = |area_water_sq_mi = |area_water_percent = |area_urban_km2 = |area_urban_sq_mi = |area_metro_km2 = |area_metro_sq_mi = |population_as_of = |population_note = |population_footnotes = |population_total = |population_density_km2 = |population_density_sq_mi = |population_metro = |population_density_metro_km2 = |population_density_metro_sq_mi = |population_urban = |population_density_urban_km2 = |population_density_urban_sq_mi = |timezone = [[Pacific Time Zone|PST]] |utc_offset = -8 |timezone_DST = PDT |utc_offset_DST = -7 |coordinates = |elevation_m = |elevation_ft = |postal_code_type = |postal_code = |area_code = |website = |blank_name = |blank_info = |blank1_name = |blank1_info = |footnotes = }} '''Newport Center''' is a business, shopping, and entertainment district located on a high bluff overlooking Newport Harbor in [[Newport Beach, California]]. Newport Center is also famously dubbed "[[Fashion Island]]" amongst locals. It was created in the early 1960s as part of [[William Pereira]]'s master plan for the [[Irvine Ranch]]. Newport Center was created as the unofficial "downtown" of the Irvine Ranch, which at the time extended all the way down to [[Pacific Coast Highway (US)|Pacific Coast Highway]].
==History== [[Image:NewportCenter-satellite.jpg|left|thumb|Satellite view of Newport Center, taken in 2005]] It was the site used for the [[1953 National Scout Jamboree]] of the [[Boy Scouts of America]].<ref>[http://www.tcninteractive.com/nb100/story_boyscouts.htm Newport Beach 100 – Landmarks and Legends] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928121306/http://www.tcninteractive.com/nb100/story_boyscouts.htm |date=2007-09-28 }}</ref> The event was held where Newport Center and [[Fashion Island]] now sit. It was the third international jamboree; the first jamboree held west of the Mississippi River and had with 50,000 scouts from all 48 states, Alaska, Hawaii, and 16 foreign countries.<ref>[http://www.ocalmanac.com/History/hi01h.htm Orange County – 1946 to 1962]</ref> It was one of the first sites considered for [[Disneyland]]. During excavation of the site for the first buildings, a considerable amount of [[petrified wood]] was discovered, indicating that a small forest once existed in the area.
The center was designed as part of a joint venture between Pereira and [[Welton Becket]], with an emphasis on [[International Style (architecture)|International Style]] architecture. The first building, at 400 Newport Center Drive, went up in 1967, with the majority of the center's buildings following in the 1970s. Although Newport Center's International Style design was mostly seen through to completion, Pereira broke his own rule by adding the [[Futurist architecture|futurist]] Pacific Mutual building in 1972, which became one of Newport Beach's most well-known architectural landmarks. Newport Center and Fashion Island were named by Orange County advertising pioneer Leland Oliver Co., Inc. which also created the advertising and public relations for many years.
The strip of land between Avocado and MacArthur roads was originally slated to be an exit spur of the Pacific Coast Freeway, which was never built. It sat largely empty until the late 2000s when a library and park were constructed on the site.
==Economy== The center occupies a large city block between Jamboree, MacArthur and San Joaquin Hills roads, and [[Pacific Coast Highway (US)|Pacific Coast Highway]]. In the center of this block is a circular road, called Newport Center Drive, with high-rise buildings encircling the outside edge of the road. Numerous businesses are located along Newport Center Drive, including insurer [[Pacific Life]], [[PIMCO]], [[Janus Capital Group]], [[Acacia Research|Acacia Research Corporation]], [[Irvine Company]], Blackwood, and law firm [[Stradling Yocca Carlson & Rauth]].
==Fashion Island== [[Image:Fashionislandnewportcenterentrance.jpg|thumb|right|Main entrance to Newport Center and Fashion Island at intersection of Newport Center Drive and Highway 1]] The center of the circle is occupied by [[Fashion Island]]. Adjacent to the complex is the very upscale [[Big Canyon Country Club]] community.
==Transportation== Newport Center Drive is accessed from the outside by five roads, which are named after the [[Channel Islands of California]]. These roads split the center into "superblocks", each of which were built and leased as separate properties.
==Gallery== <gallery class="center" > File:Fashion_Island_Newport_Center_Driver_Photo_D_Ramey_Logan.jpg File:Newport Center Photo D Ramey Logan.jpg|Newport Center with Balboa in the foreground File:NewportCenterPier(Small).JPG|Newport Center from Balboa Peninsula File:Newport Center Skyline and Santa Ana Mountains.jpg|Newport Skyline File:Irvine company hq.jpg|Irvine Company's HQ in Newport Center File:Fashion Island - Vlad 89.JPG|Fashion Island in Newport Center File:Pacificlifeheadquarters.jpg|Pacific Life's HQ </gallery>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{coord|33.616|-117.8761|type:landmark_region:US-CA|display=title}}
[[Category:Buildings and structures in Newport Beach, California]] [[Category:Business parks of the United States]] [[Category:William Pereira buildings]]

{{advert|date=August 2014}} '''One Block Off the Grid''', or '''1BOG''', is a US [[solar energy|solar]] company that works with the largest solar providers in the nation to create a single online destination for solar energy options. Originally, it was formed as an example of a [[social entrepreneurship]] model that promotes [[community development]], [[social activism]] and personal responsibility. 1BOG currently operates in approximately fifteen US cities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crunchbase.com/company/1bog|title=One Block off the Grid|publisher=Crunchbase}}</ref>
One Block Off the Grid's name is a metaphor for freeing the world from its dependency on non-renewable power sources, one block at a time.
==Business model== 1BOG has a solution for the pain point the solar industry has experienced up to now in the residential market—large upfront costs make many homeowners reluctant or unable to manage the purchase. One executive told Venturebeat that outside of a few very tiny neighborhoods in San Francisco, the company finds that about 80% of its customers need financing: “It’s that difference between paying about $10,000 and just a thousand up front,” he said.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2009/03/31/sunrun-teams-with-virgance-to-finance-solar-for-consumers/#LDjodItG0siv8Gig.99 |title=SunRun teams with Virgance to finance solar for consumers |date=March 31, 2009 |publisher=VentureBeat |author=Chris Morrison}}</ref>
Originally, 1BOG used [[community organizing]] techniques such as house parties, [[canvassing]], and [[Volunteering|volunteer]] recruitment in addition to [[social networking]] and traditional marketing techniques to obtain a critical mass of consumers in a given city who are interested in learning more about solar technology.<ref name="nytimes.com">[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/05/magazine/05wwln-consumed-t.html?ref=earth Rob Walker, “Panel Discussion,” The New York Times Magazine, April 3, 2009.]</ref>
When a homeowner first expressed an interest in solar, 1BOG would evaluate the roof to determine whether the option made sense for the homeowner. If solar was a good option for the particular house and the homeowner's electric bill was more than a certain amount, 1BOG would identified similar solar prospects in the area and group them together, leveraging that bargaining power with solar installers to establish a lower cost. As one customer said:
:We wouldn't have done it otherwise...just that much additional money that I didn't quite have.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marketplace.org/topics/sustainability/community-solar-power-within-reach |title=Community solar power is within reach |author=Marketplace |publisher=American Public Media |date=June 23, 2009 |accessdate=2012-12-27}}</ref>
Recently 1BOG has been a leading force in the move to solar leasing, a newer model which applies to solar technology a financing structure similar to an automobile lease. As many as 40% of solar customers now lease rather than purchase their solar equipment outright.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mnn.com/money/green-workplace/stories/how-does-solar-leasing-work |title=How does solar leasing work? |author=Amy Feinstein |publisher=Mother Nature Network |date=March 1, 2012 |accessdate=2012-12-27}}</ref>
==Campaigns== 1BOG’s [[Bay Area]] pilot campaign in 2008 organized 42 [[solar power|solar]] customers. [[Real Goods]] Solar won the bid for that project.<ref>[http://sfbay.1bog.org/san-francisco-solar-sep-08/ 1BOG Cities: Past Campaigns]</ref> The second Bay Area campaign signed up over 1200 members. This time the chosen installer was [[SolarCity]]. "What really sealed it for us was their offer of free demand-side energy monitoring and a free home-energy audit to 1BOG participants," according to 1BOG general manager Dave Llorens. "The audit shows people where to find the best bang-for-the-buck on green home improvements, while the new monitoring technology empowers people to make continued and measurable improvements to their energy efficiency." <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/pressRelease/idUS165284+06-Jan-2009+BW20090106|title=1BOG and SolarCity Announce Bay Area-Wide Residential Solar Program |publisher=Reuters |date=January 6, 2009 |accessdate=2012-12-26}}</ref>
In addition to the [[Bay Area]], 1BOG currently has campaigns at various stages in [[Los Angeles]], [[San Diego]], [[New Orleans]], [[Denver]], [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]], [[Sacramento]], [[Washington, D.C.|Washington]], [[Aspen]], [[Austin]], [[Bergen County]] ([[New Jersey]]), [[Boston]], [[Brooklyn]], [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]], [[Miami]], [[Portland, Oregon|Portland]] and [[Seattle]]. 1BOG is currently working with a variety of solar providers, and plans to branch out into [[solar thermal]] installations and home [[energy conservation]].
==1BOG Logo – a.k.a. "Plugfoot"== The 1BOG logo, often referred to as “the Bogman”, is the result of a crowdsourcing branding effort led by Sylvia Ventura in April 2008. The logo challenge resulted in over 150 submissions. The Bogman was the finalist.
==Key people== 1BOG was founded in 2008 by [[Dave Llorens]] (CEO), Sylvia Ventura, and Dan Barahona. In 2012, 1BOG was acquired by Pure Energies Group.
==History== In early 2007, Ventura and Barahona spent three months researching solar power for their San Francisco home. They became expert in solar technologies, electric utility rates and metering, and local and federal tax incentives and rebates and found that many people were interested in residential solar technology, but few knew anything about it, nor where it was feasible. So Ventura and Barahona created advocacy and outreach website Solar4SF.org<ref>{{Cite web|title=Solar4SF.org - Solar Energy Advocacy for San Francisco and the Bay Area |accessdate=2013-10-17 |date=2007-10-09 |url=http://www.solar4sf.org/ |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071009083659/http://www.solar4sf.org/ |archivedate=October 9, 2007 }}</ref> in an effort to share their research and promote solar with for easy-to-understand information and evaluation criteria for [[San Francisco Bay Area|Bay Area]] residents.
In March 2008 Barahona and Ventura imagined an entire city block in which every residence would go solar. The collective buying power of this relatively larger group of solar consumers would allow them to negotiate better pricing from installers. The goal of taking one city block off the grid led to their new venture’s name, One Block Off the Grid, soon shortened to the acronym '''1BOG'''.
The difficulty of convincing every single homeowner in a city block to commit to a major purchase however made Ventura and Barahona focus on aggregates of a ‘virtual city block’ representing about 200 [[Kilowatt#Kilowatt|kilowatts]]. They met Llorens, a solar consultant and the co-founder of SolarPowerRocks.com,<ref>[http://www.SolarPowerRocks.com Here's how you get the most from solarpowerrocks.com: | Solar Power Rocks<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> a site that provides solar information for all fifty states. The three agreed to build 1BOG together.
1BOG officially launched on June 5, 2008, the day after San Francisco enacted the largest solar incentive in the city’s history. It was followed by numerous grassroot and social media efforts to educate and recruit San Francisco residents. Within one month 200 people had signed up on 1BOG’s website to receive an evaluation. The San Francisco pilot helped convert 42 homes to solar energy by negotiating a 48% reduction from list price, and generated over $800,000 in local solar installation sales.
The San Francisco Chronicle<ref>[http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2008/10/10/HOMS12TISR.DTL "Shining a light on S.F. solar options," San Francisco Chronicle, October 11, 2008]</ref> documented the success of the campaign in an in-depth article on October 11, 2008. The press coverage drove another 400 new 1BOG members within two days and helped propel 1BOG forward on future campaigns. Over the following months 1BOG was featured prominently in [[Huffington Post]], [[CNET]], [[New York Times]], [[TIME]], [[Wall Street Journal]], [[Wired (magazine)|Wired]], [[TreeHugger]], and others.
By the end of October 1BOG had seeded campaigns in seven additional cities including New York, Seattle, Portland, Colorado, and San Jose and Oakland in the Bay Area. The company was acquired in November 2008 by [[San Francisco]]-based [[Virgance]], a company that promotes large-scale [[social activism]] through [[market-based]] methods.<ref>{{cite news|title= "Change We Can Profit From," The Economist, January 29, 2009|url=http://www.economist.com/business/displaystory.cfm?story_id=13031214|work=|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5gp2hfTcZ|archivedate=2009-05-16|deadurl=no|accessdate=2009-05-13|date=January 29, 2009}}</ref>
In 2009 1BOG formed an alliance with [[SunRun]] to offer [[financing]] options aimed at lowering the upfront costs traditionally associated with [[solar power|solar]] installations.<ref>{{cite web|title= Chris Morrison, "SunRun teams with Virgance to finance solar for consumers," VentureBeat, March 31, 2009.|url=https://venturebeat.com/2009/03/31/sunrun-teams-with-virgance-to-finance-solar-for-consumers/|deadurl=no|accessdate=2012-12-26|date=2009-03-31}}</ref>
It was acquired in 2010 by [[Virgance]], a for-profit Web 2.0 company with plans to use social media to make activism interesting and fun.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crunchbase.com/company/virgance|title=Virgance|publisher=Crunchbase}}</ref> It remained however more active and widely known than its parent company.
It was bought in 2012 by Pure Energies Group, a closely held [[Toronto]]-based [[solar panel]] manufacturer that credited its ability to make the purchase to [[Ontario]]'s 2009 [[Green Energy Act 2009|Green Energy Act]]. Pure Energies vice president Chris Stern would not give a price for the acquisition but said he expected the new enterprise to be making $50 million by the end of 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/business/article/1244070--green-energy-act-powers-ontario-firm |title=Green Energy Act powers Ontario firm |publisher=thestar.com |date=August 20, 2012 |author=John Spears |accessdate=2012-12-27}}</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=October 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{Globalize|article|New Zealand|Australia|reason=Such registers exist elsewhere. The name is general and so should the article in my opinion. For example the "personal property security registration system" of Ontario, Canada (ontario.ca/page/register-security-interest-or-search-lien-access-now). These also exist in Vanuatu (vfsc.vu/vanuatu-personal-property-securities-registry/), Tonga (ppsa.to/), Malawi (ppsr.registrargeneral.gov.mw/), Papua New Guinea (ipa.gov.pg/ppsa), and Jamaica (nsippregistry.gov.jm/public/aboutfilingoffice.aspx).|date=August 2017}} {{Infobox Government agency |logo = |logo_width = 140 px |logo_caption = |seal = |seal_width = |seal_caption = |formed = |preceding1 = |dissolved = |superseding = |jurisdiction = New Zealand (and Australia in May 2011) |headquarters = |employees = |budget = |minister1_name = |minister1_pfo = |minister2_name = |minister2_pfo = |chief1_name = |chief1_position = |chief2_name = |chief2_position = |parent_agency =[[New Zealand Ministry of Economic Development]]
[[Australian Financial Security Authority]] |child1_agency = |website = [http://www.ppsr.govt.nz/ ppsr.govt.nz]
[http://www.ppsr.gov.au/ ppsr.gov.au] |footnotes = }} The '''Personal Property Securities Register''' ('''PPSR''') is an electronic register that allows security interests in personal property to be registered and searched in accordance with the New Zealand Personal Property Securities Act 1999{{cite web|url=http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/1999/0126/latest/DLM45900.html?search=ts_act_personal+property_resel&p=1&sr=1|title=Personal Property Securities Act 1999}} (the Act) and the Australian Personal Property Securities Act 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.comlaw.gov.au/ComLaw/Legislation/ActCompilation1.nsf/0/05083AE887C340DACA257761007AD73B?OpenDocument|title=Personal Property Securities Act 2009|publisher=comlaw.gov.au}} The New Zealand PPSR is maintained by the [[New Zealand Companies Office]], an agency of the [[Ministry of Business, Innovation and Employment]]. The [[Australian Financial Security Authority]] (AFSA) is the Australian Government agency responsible for administering the Australian PPS Register. ==Electronic register== The New Zealand PPSR is a wholly electronic register available to the public 24 hours a day, 365 days a year. It provides online searching, registration and maintenance of [[financing statement]]s. The Australian PPS Register commenced operation on 30 January 2012.{{cite web|url=https://transact.ppsr.gov.au/ppsr/Home|title=Access the Australian PPS Register}} ==History== The Act reformed the law relating to security interests in personal property and established the PPSR. The PPSR became operational on 1 May 2002. It replaced a number of existing registers including the Chattels Register, Motor Vehicle Securities Register and the Register of Company Charges.{{cite web|url=http://www.ppsr.govt.nz/cms/about-us|title=About the New Zealand PPSR}} In December 2009, the Australian Personal Property Securities Act 2009 ("the PPS Act") was passed. The Australian PPS Act establishes the Personal Property Securities Register ("the PPS Register").{{cite web|url=http://www.ppsr.gov.au/ABOUTTHEREGISTER|title=About the Australian PPSR}} The Australian PPSR became operational on the 30th of January, 2012. It replaced a number of existing registers including the Australian Shipping Register, New South Wales Register of Encumbered Vehicles, Queensland Register of Encumbered Vehicles, South Australian Vehicle Securities Register, Tasmanian Motor Vehicle Securities Register, Vic Roads Vehicle Securities Register, and Western Australian Register of Encumbered Vehicles.{{cite web|url=https://www.ppsr.gov.au/previous-securities-registers-and-migrated-data|title=Previous securities registers}} ==Activities== The PPSR is used by both secured parties (creditors) and consumers. === Registration === Registering a security interest on the PPSR may give creditors a better chance of recovering a debt if a debtor defaults. The Act contains rules for determining priority between security interests in the same collateral (see section 66 of the Act). If a creditor does not register a security interest and a debtor is adjudicated bankrupt or is placed into liquidation, secured creditors will be prioritised when payments are made or assets distributed. === Searching === The PPSR can be used to assess the level of risk that a debtor may represent to a creditor. Before entering into a contractual relationship with a debtor, a creditor may search the PPSR to check whether they may pose a risk. It possible for potential creditors to: * Search a debtor to determine whether there are any existing security interests over their collateral, this may mean they have a number of existing debts. * Search a debtor to identify if the piece of collateral they are offering you as security has been used as security for another party and if so, someone else will have priority over this collateral. * Search collateral on the PPSR before buying an item. Check to see if the item is encumbered with an existing registered security. If you are purchasing a car, you may search on the registration number or VIN. Alternatively, conduct a debtor search (against the seller of the goods). Consumers may also search the PPSR before buying an item of personal property to check that there is no money owing. This is particularly important if purchasing a second hand car privately – it is possible to search the PPSR using the VIN (Vehicle Identification Number) to check whether there may be money owed (registered security interests) on the vehicle. The PPSR also correlates information from the [[NEVDIS]] (National Exchange of Vehicle and Driver Information System) database[http://www.austroads.com.au/drivers-vehicles/nevdis National Exchange of Vehicle and Driver Information System (NEVDIS)], [[Austroads]] to provide write-off history and stolen vehicle data in the form of a PPSR certificate, which can be issued upon successful completion of a serial number (VIN) search. ==The New Zealand Companies Office== As well as the PPSR, the [[New Zealand Companies Office]] is also responsible for the administration of the following registers: * The New Zealand companies register and the Overseas companies register. These are electronic registers that provide the online searching, incorporation and maintenance services for New Zealand registered companies and overseas companies registered to carry on business in New Zealand. *The Incorporated Societies Register (including charitable trusts). *The Motor Vehicle Traders Register (MVTR) – an electronic register that contains information on all registered motor vehicle traders, and information about the trader's business, including its physical address. === International activities and involvement === The New Zealand Companies Office is a founding member of the [[Corporate Registers Forum]] (an international association of corporate registries) and is an International member of the [[International Association of Commercial Administrators]] (IACA). ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140324191708/http://www.ppsr.gov.au/pages/ppsr.aspx] Official Australian Government site for PPSR, including information to help businesses and consumers understand the Australian PPSR * [https://www.afsa.gov.au/about-us/ppsr/personal-property-securities-register-ppsr] Official site of AFSA, including more information about PPSR in Australia. '''Process architecture''' is the structural design of general process systems. It applies to fields such as computers (software, hardware, networks, etc.), business processes ([[enterprise architecture]], policy and procedures, logistics, project management, etc.), and any other process system of varying degrees of [[complexity]].<ref name=parch>Dawis, E. P., J. F. Dawis, Wei-Pin Koo (2001). Architecture of Computer-based Systems using Dualistic Petri Nets. Systems, Man, and Cybernetics, 2001 IEEE International Conference on Volume 3, 2001 Page(s):1554 - 1558 vol.3</ref>
Processes are defined as having inputs, outputs and the energy required to transform inputs to outputs. Use of energy during transformation also implies a passage of time: a process takes [[Real-time computing|real time]] to perform its associated action. A process also requires space for input/output objects and transforming objects to exist: a process uses real space.
A process system is a specialized [[system]] of processes. Processes are composed of processes. Complex processes are made up of several processes that are in turn made up of several processes. This results in an overall structural [[hierarchy]] of [[abstraction]]. If the process system is studied hierarchically, it is easier to understand and manage; therefore, process architecture requires the ability to consider process systems hierarchically. Graphical modeling of process architectures is considered by [[dualistic Petri nets]]. Mathematical consideration of process architectures may be found in [[Calculus of communicating systems|CCS]] and the [[π-calculus]].
The structure of a process system, or its architecture, can be viewed as a dualistic relationship of its [[infrastructure]] and suprastructure.<ref name=parch/><ref name=ss7arch>Dawis, E. P. (2001). Architecture of an SS7 Protocol Stack on a Broadband Switch Platform using Dualistic Petri Nets. Communications, Computers and signal Processing, 2001. PACRIM. 2001 IEEE Pacific Rim Conference on Volume 1, 2001 Page(s):323 - 326 vol.1</ref> The infrastructure describes a process system's component parts and their interactions. The suprastructure considers the super system of which the process system is a part. (Suprastructure should not be confused with [[superstructure]], which is actually part of the infrastructure built for (external) support.) As one traverses the process architecture from one level of abstraction to the next, infrastructure becomes the basis for suprastructure and vice versa as one looks within a system or without.
Requirements for a process system are derived at every hierarchical level.<ref name=ss7arch/> Black-box requirements for a system come from its suprastructure. Customer requirements are black-box requirements near, if not at, the top of a process architecture's hierarchy. White-box requirements, such as engineering rules, programming [[Syntax (programming languages)|syntax]], etc., come from the process system's infrastructure.
Process systems are a dualistic phenomenon of change/no-change or form/transform and as such, are well-suited to being modeled by the bipartite [[Petri nets]] modeling system and in particular, process-class [[dualistic Petri nets]] where processes can be simulated in real time and space and studied hierarchically.

{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} [[File:Grave of Robert Cox MP, Dean Cemetery.JPG|thumb|grave of Robert Cox MP, Dean Cemetery]] [[File:Memorial to Robert Cox MP, St Cuthbert's Churchyard, Edinburgh.jpg|thumb|Memorial to Robert Cox MP, St Cuthbert's Churchyard, Edinburgh]] '''Robert J. Cox''' [[FRSE]] (6 May 1845 – 2 June 1899) was a [[Scottish people|Scottish]] [[gelatine]] and [[glue]] manufacturer and [[Liberal Unionist Party|Liberal Unionist]] politician.
==Family and education==
Cox was the son of George Cox of [[Gorgie]], a district of [[Edinburgh]] and his wife Isabella (née Craig), the daughter of Robert Craig, a surgeon from [[Peebles]].<ref>The Times, 19 July 1895 p15</ref> He was educated at [[Loretto School]], the [[University of St Andrews]] and the [[University of Edinburgh]].<ref>''Who was Who''; OUP, 2007</ref> In 1875, he married Harriet Sophia Bennett (1850-1905), the daughter of the eminent physician and [[physiologist]] [[John Hughes Bennett|Professor John Hughes Bennett]] of the Institute of Medicine at the University of Edinburgh.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.onc.ed.ac.uk/jhbl/history.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-12-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120204091037/http://www.onc.ed.ac.uk/jhbl/history.htm |archivedate=4 February 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> They may have had a son, also Robert Cox, who died in 1952.<ref>http://thepeerage.com/p12534.htm#i125337</ref>
==Career== From 1874, Cox was the sole partner of J & G Cox, Ltd gelatine and glue manufacturers of Edinburgh.<ref>The Times, 19 July 1895 p15</ref> He was later Chairman of the [[Madelvic Motor Carriage Company]] Ltd of [[Granton, Edinburgh|Granton]].<ref>''The Motor Car Journal, Volume 1'', Cordingley & Co, 1899 p217</ref>
In 1885 he was living at 34 Drumsheugh Gardens in Edinburgh's West End.<ref>Edinburgh and Leith Post Office Directory 1885-6</ref>
==Politics== Cox took an interest in local politics. At one time or another he sat as a member of the Mid Lothian County Council, Edinburgh Parish Council (of which he was Chairman of the [[Local Government (Scotland) Act 1894|Landward Committee]]), Edinburgh Town Council and the [[History of education in Scotland|School Board]].<ref>The Times, 19 July 1895 p15</ref>
Cox first stood for [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|Parliament]] at a by-election in the [[Kirkcaldy Burghs (UK Parliament constituency)|Kirkcaldy Burghs constituency]] on 11 March 1892.<ref>F W S Craig, ''British Parliamentary Election Results 1885–1918'';Macmillan, 1974 p514</ref> Cox was selected as the Unionist candidate for the seat, which had become vacant on the death of the sitting [[Liberal Party (UK)|Liberal]] [[Member of Parliament|MP]], [[George Campbell (1824–1892)|Sir George Campbell]].<ref>The Times, 27 February 1892 p12</ref> However Cox was unsuccessful, the seat being held for the Liberals by a majority of 1,036 votes,<ref>F W S Craig, ''British Parliamentary Election Results 1885–1918'';Macmillan, 1974 p514</ref> by [[Henry Dalziel, 1st Baron Dalziel of Kirkcaldy|J H Dalziel]], a journalist and later newspaper proprietor.<ref>The Times, 27 February 1892 p12</ref>
Cox did not contest the [[United Kingdom general election, 1892|1892 general election]] but in June 1895 the Unionist Association of the [[Edinburgh East (UK Parliament constituency)|East Edinburgh division]] approached him as a possible candidate.<ref>The Times, 26 June 1895 p10</ref> The Liberal MP for the seat, [[Robert Wallace (Edinburgh MP)|Robert Wallace]] was reported to have fallen foul of his local Liberal Association on the issue of [[Irish Home Rule]] and they had selected a [[Martin White (politician)|Mr J Martin White]] to fight the seat instead. It was thought possible that Wallace would stand as an independent and create a three-cornered contest.<ref>The Times, 26 June 1895 p10</ref> In the end Wallace and the East Edinburgh Liberals must have mended their fences as Wallace stood again as a Liberal at the [[United Kingdom general election, 1895|1895 general election]]<ref>F W S Craig, ''British Parliamentary Election Results 1885–1918'';Macmillan, 1974 p498</ref> and White successfully contested [[Forfar (UK Parliament constituency)|Fofarshire]] in the Liberal interest.<ref>F W S Craig, ''British Parliamentary Election Results 1885–1918'';Macmillan, 1974 p541</ref>
Cox declined the offer to stand in Edinburgh East (or it was withdrawn) and instead was adopted as Liberal Unionist candidate for the [[Edinburgh South (UK Parliament constituency)|Edinburgh South division]]. He narrowly defeated the sitting Liberal MP, [[Herbert Paul]], turning a Liberal majority of 431 into a Unionist one of just 97.<ref>F W S Craig, ''British Parliamentary Election Results 1885–1918'';Macmillan, 1974 p499</ref>
==Other appointments and interests== Cox served as a [[Justice of the Peace]] for [[Midlothian|Mid Lothian]] and was sometime [[Deputy Lieutenant]] for the [[County of Edinburgh]].<ref>''Who was Who''; OUP, 2007</ref> He also served as President of the [[Rights of way in Scotland|Scottish Rights of Way Association]].<ref>The Times, 13 December 1898 p7</ref> Cox had a wide range of intellectual interests. He was particularly concerned with philosophy and [[astronomy]]. He was a Fellow of the [[Royal Society of Edinburgh]], a Fellow of the [[Royal Scottish Society of Arts]] and Vice-President of the Edinburgh Philosophical Institution.<ref>The Times, 19 July 1895 p15</ref> He employed [[William Peck (astronomer)|William Peck]] to run a private [[observatory]] at [[Murrayfield]] and later donated his telescopes to the [[City Observatory]] on [[Calton Hill]].<ref>http://www.astronomyedinburgh.org/publications/booklet/</ref> In 1899, Cox was elected a Fellow of the [[Society of Antiquaries of Scotland]].<ref>http://ads.ahds.ac.uk/catalogue/adsdata/arch-352-1/dissemination/pdf/vol_034/34_001_003.pdf</ref> Cox was also a member of the [[Royal Company of Archers]], the ceremonial unit that served as the [[Sovereign's Bodyguard]] in Scotland.<ref>The Times, 19 July 1895 p15</ref>
==Death== Cox was in poor health towards the end of his life. He died at [[Aix-les-Bains]] on 2 June 1899, aged 54.<ref>''Annual register'';J Dodsley, 1900 p154</ref>
He is buried in [[Dean Cemetery]] in Edinburgh, in its north-east section not far from the entrance. He is also memorialised on his parent's grave in St Cuthbert's churchyard in the city centre.

{{refimprove|date=December 2015}} {{expand Portuguese|Família Schürmann|date=July 2012}} [[Image:Schurmann name.jpg|framed|right|<small>''Schürmann Family''</small>]] '''The Schürmann Family''' is the first [[Brazil]]ian family to circumnavigate the world on a [[sailboat]] and the only Brazilian family to have done it three times. The family has been active around the world through their online school program, as well as their films and TV programs such as [[Rede Globo]], [[National Geographic Channel|National Geographic]] among others.
In 1984 [[Vilfredo schurmann|Vilfredo]], Heloisa and their children left their home, work and school and set off from [[Florianópolis]], the capital city of the State of Santa Catarina, in southern Brazil, to pursue their dream: circumnavigate the world on a sailboat. Their children, Pierre, David and Wilhelm, were 15, 10 and 7 years old, respectively. On this first adventure, the Schürmann Family spent 10 years at sea.
In 1997 the Schürmann Family began their second great adventure [[Magellan Global Adventure]]. The goal was to retrace the route sailed by [[Ferdinand Magellan]]’s fleet, the first complete circumnavigation of the planet's history. For this adventure, apart from the Vilfredo and Heloisa only their son [[David Schurmann|David Schürmann]] and Kat, their 5-year-old daughter went along. Magellan Global Adventure was followed by more than 1,5 million people, from 44 countries. Every month the adventure’s filmed reports, were broadcast internationally, with an average of 40 million television viewers in Brazil and many more around the world. After 30 months, the Schürmanns' yacht returned to Brazil.
In 2011, the Schürmanns led the expedition that for the first time in Brazilian history a [[World War II]] German [[U-boat]] was located in its waters. After 9 years research and 2 years of seagoing searches the U-513 was located 85km east of their hometown of [[Florianópolis]]. The find was announced worldwide on June 17th 2011, when the Schürmanns produced images of a Side-scanning sonar.
In Vilfredo’s words, “the bond that keeps our family so united is that we were, are and will be dreamers. Forever.”
On September 21, 2014, the Schurmann Family set off on their new sustainable sailboat to sail around the world for the third circumnavigation: The Orient Expedition followed the routes of the Chinese that, according to controversial theories, were the first sailors to travel around the globe, before Ferdinand Magellan. The new project brought aboard innovation, technology and sustainability. The children Pierre and David (land crew leader) participated in some sections of the adventure whereas Wilhelm (Skipper) was onboard throughout the expedition. The youngest, Kat will be symbolically present by inspiring the name of the new sailboat. And, for the first time, the crew gets a representative of the third generation: Emmanuel, he will accompany his grandparents throughout the voyage.
The Orient Expedition also involves important actions, such as an educational project in partnership with Estácio and the production of National Geographic and a feature documentary. Based on samples collected during the trip, the Biological Oceanography Department of a renowned university (USP) have conducted a study with quality analyses of waters and planktons where the boat sailed
==Members== The family members are: Vilfredo, Heloisa, Pierre, David, Wilhelm and Kat Schürmann (d. 2006<ref name=obituary>{{cite web|last=Schurmann|first=Heloisa|title=Família Schürmann: 20 anos de aventuras:|url=http://www.schurmann.com.br/familiaaventura/a_ultimas_conteudo_eng.asp?id_noticias=128|work=Latest News|publisher=Schurmann Family|accessdate=29 September 2011}}</ref>).
==The family in media== The family has released 4 best sellers in Brazil, and one box office hit documentary film:
===Books=== * ''Ao Vento'' (2010) ''Portuguese/English'' by David Schurmann * ''Pequeno Segredo'' (2010) ''Portuguese'' by Heloisa Schurmann * ''Pequeno Segredo'' (2013) ''Italian'' by Heloisa Schurmann * ''Em Busca do Sonho'' (2006) ''not yet translated'' by Heloisa Schurmann * ''Momentos De uma Aventura'' (2001) ''Portuguese/English'' by Vilfredo Schurmann * ''Um Mundo de Aventuras'' (2002) ''not yet translated'' by Heloisa Schurmann * ''10 Anos No Mar'' (1995) by Heloisa Schurmann
===Films & TV=== * ''Schurmann Family - Orient Expedition'' (TV series) * ''O Mundo em Duas Voltas'' (The World Twice Around or The World in Two Round Trips) 2007 (film) * ''Em Busca do Sonho'' (film) * ''Magellan Global Adventure'' (TV series) * ''Schurmann Family 20 years'' (TV series)

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Serhiy Kuzmenko
Сергій Кузьменко | image = Kuzmenko S.A.JPG | imagesize = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1975|1|22}} | birth_place = [[Oleksandriia]], [[Ukraine]], [[USSR]] | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = state official, businessman | salary = | networth = | spouse = | website = | footnotes = | children = 2 }} '''Serhiy Kuzmenko''' ({{lang-uk|Сергій Анатолійович Кузьменко}}, born 27 November 1954) is a Ukrainian politician, businessman and state official. He currently serves as head of the [[Kirovohrad Regional State Administration]] (Governor of Kirovohrad Oblast) since 16 September 2014. ==Biography== After graduating the Kirovohrad National Technical University in 1997, Kuzmenko worked at the family business Holovkivska Agro-Firm out of [[Holovkivka, Oleksandriia Raion|Holovkivka]] which in 2000 became known as "UkrAhroKom". In 2002, he went into politics becoming a council deputy of the Oleksandriia Raion council and in 2010–2012 was head of the Oleksandriia Raion State Administration. In 2011 Kuzmenko graduated the Dnipropetrovsk Regional Institute of the [[National Academy for Public Administration under the President of Ukraine|National Academy for Public Administration]]. In 2012 Kuzmenko became a deputy head of the Kirovohrad Regional State Administration, but at the end of 2012 was elected as a member of [[Party of Regions]] to the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukrainian parliament). After the [[Euromaidan]], he left the party. At the end of September 2014, Kuzmenko was appointed head of the [[Kirovohrad Regional State Administration]]. There were protests against this appointment, activists accused Kuzmenko of having supported the 2013 so called "[[anti-protest laws in Ukraine|anti-protest laws]] and of having hired "[[Titushky]]" to beat up [[Euromaidan]] protesters.https://www.unian.ua/m/politics/988271-lyustratsiya-v-regionah-kirovogradschina-povstala-proti-vojdya-titushok.html Kuzmenko denied all these charges.https://www.unian.ua/m/politics/988271-lyustratsiya-v-regionah-kirovogradschina-povstala-proti-vojdya-titushok.html He also added that he was never part of the so-called "[[anti-Maidan]].https://www.unian.ua/m/politics/988271-lyustratsiya-v-regionah-kirovogradschina-povstala-proti-vojdya-titushok.html ==Business and philanthropy== Along with his father, Kuzmenko own a family business known as "UkrAhroKom" which owns over {{convert|75000|ha|acre|abbr=on}} of agrarian area in eastern and southeastern portions of [[Kirovohrad Oblast]]. The company owns the Oleksandriia Sugar Plant, transportation company "Hermes Trading", a couple of livestock farms including "Petrykivske moloko" (Petrykivka Milk), four [[grain elevator]]s, a river terminal in [[Svitlovodsk]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20161229120559/http://ukragrocom.com/index.php/ru/view/our_history/2/all History of UkrAhroKom]. UkrAhroKom official website. Kuzmenko was the owner of [[FC UkrAhroKom Holovkivka]] that existed in 2008-2014. After acquiring [[PFC Oleksandriya]] from [[Mykola Lavrenko]] in 2013,[https://web.archive.org/web/20161229122834/http://www.alsport.com.ua/?p=1280 FC Kuzmenko and FC Oleksandriya]. Alsport. 4 January 2014 he merged both clubs under the name [[FC Oleksandriya]] in 2014.[https://web.archive.org/web/20161229122707/http://fco.com.ua/index.php/klub/istoriya History of FC Oleksandriya]. [[FC Oleksandriya]] website. ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20161229120823/http://dovidka.com.ua/user/?code=456531 Brief profile] at the Official Ukraine Today {{s-start}} {{s-sports}} {{succession box | title=President of [[FC Oleksandriya]] | before=[[Mykola Lavrenko]] | after=incumbent | years=2013–}} {{succession box | title=President of [[FC UkrAhroKom Holovkivka]] | before=new post | after=post disbanded | years=2008–2014}} {{s-off}} {{succession box | title=Governor of Kirovohrad Oblast | before=[[Oleksandr Petik]] | after=incumbent | years=2014–}} {{s-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kuzmenko, Serhiy}} [[Category:Ukrainian businesspeople]] [[Category:1975 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Oleksandriia]] [[Category:Party of Regions politicians]] [[Category:Independent politicians in Ukraine]] [[Category:Ukrainian football chairmen and investors]] [[Category:FC Oleksandriya]] [[Category:Governors of Kirovohrad Oblast]] [[Category:Seventh convocation members of the Verkhovna Rada]]

'''Sourcing advisory''' is the use of third-party (external entity) advice during the sourcing process. As such, it may refer to advice sought during [[outsourcing]], [[offshoring]] or [[global sourcing]].
==Sourcing advisors== Given the strategic nature of the advisory and the prevalence of [[Global sourcing|sourcing]] amongst global organizations, most [[management consulting]] firms today offer sourcing advisory services. In addition, there exist a host of specialized sourcing adivsory firms that focus on providing sourcing advisory and research inputs to the industry. Sourcing advisors can also be independent freelance consultants.
In recent years software tools to automate sourcing advisory emerged. Building on [[Software as a Service]] (SaaS), the trade mark "Sourcing Advisory as a Service" (SAaaS) is used in the market.<ref>[http://www.plixos.com/en/it-outsourcing-services/saaas-sourcing-advisory-as-a-service "SAaaS - Automation in Sourcing Advisory"]</ref>
==Services== The range of services provided by sourcing advisory firms include:<ref>[http://www.globusresearch.com/services-sourcing.aspx Services Sourcing: Outsourcing and Offshoring (www.globusresearch.com)]</ref> * Helping buyers identify functions to be outsourced or offshored (sourcing opportunity areas, shoring strategy) * Helping buyers identify and evaluate capable suppliers (provider selection <ref>[https://www.resiport.com Software Outsourcing Advisory as a Service]</ref>) * Advising buyers through stages of the [[outsourcing]] transaction * Helping buyers manage established [[outsourcing]] relationships (in issues such as [[governance]] and [[change management]]); improve sourcing contracts * Helping buyers re-negotiate or renew transactions * Support escalation management * Execution of operational audits with the aim of project recovery * Research relevant to the sourcing industry
==See also== * [[Management consulting]] * [[Outsourcing]] * [[Offshoring]] * [[Global sourcing]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Sourcing Advisory}} [[Category:Offshoring]] [[Category:Offshore finance]] [[Category:Legal entities]] [[Category:Business terms]] [[Category:Outsourcing]] [[Category:International business]]

{{ref improve|date=October 2012}} In the context of [[Production (economics)|production]], a '''split-off point''' is the point at which joint products appear in the production process.<ref>Wouters, Mark; Selto, Frank H.; Hilton, Ronald W.; Maher, Michael W. (2012): ''Cost Management: Strategies for Business Decisions'', International Edition, Berkshire (UK), p. 532.</ref>
Example:
When the Entity is carrying on the business with two subsidiaries,one subsidiary is making huge profits and another subsidiary making huge losses.....while preparing the financial statements of the company, the company showing no profit and no loss,and these will not attract the investors.The company got the idea to form independent companies so that it can be easily measurable and it can decide the future of the companies and where developments required for the companies.
== See also == * [[Joint cost]]

{{Infobox SCOTUS case |Litigants=Stratton's Independence, Ltd. v. Howbert |ArgueDate=October 21 |ArgueYear=1913 |DecideDate=December 1 |DecideYear=1913 |FullName=Stratton's Independence, Limited v. Howbert, Collector of Internal Revenue |USVol=231 |USPage=399 |ParallelCitations=34 S. Ct. 136; 58 [[Lawyers' Edition|L. Ed.]] 285; 1913 [[LexisNexis|U.S. LEXIS]] 2577 |Prior= |Subsequent= |Holding= |SCOTUS=1912–1914 |Majority=Pitney |JoinMajority= |Dissent=White |JoinDissent=McKenna, Holmes |LawsApplied= }} '''''Stratton's Independence, Ltd. v. Howbert''''', 231 U.S. 399 (1913),<ref name=supreme>{{ussc|name=Stratton's Independence, Ltd. v. Howbert|link=|volume=231|page=399|pin=|year=1913}}.</ref>, was a case before the [[U.S. Supreme Court]] that addressed the question of [[Corporate tax|corporate taxation]].
==Case== The case was argued on October 21, 1913, and decided on December 1, 1913.
Stratton's Independence, Limited, a British corporation that owned and operated mines in [[Colorado]], sued in a district court to recover taxes it had paid under protest in accordance with the provisions of the [[Corporation Tax Act of 1909]]. During the year 1909, the firm had had gross sales of $284,682.85 and costs of $190,939.42, resulting in a profit of $93,743.43. In 1910, the figures had been similar. <ref name=supreme/>
===Plaintiff's argument=== Stratton's contended that the mining and sale of [[ore]] was an essentially different sort of activity than manufacturing, because it involved the depletion and sale of capital, and should therefore not be taxed in the same way, because taxing the sale of ore amounted to taxing capital.<ref name=supreme/>
===Majority opinion=== [[Justice Pitney]], in the majority opinion, stated that the case raised three questions. The first was whether or not the Corporate Tax Act applied to mining corporations. The second question raised was whether or not proceeds from mining activities constituted "income" by the definition of the act. The final question related to whether or not ore sales were considered income and therefore if the mining corporation could deduct the value of the ore in place before it was mined as depreciation. The court answered the first two questions in the affirmative, but not the third. Mining, Justice Pitney argued, is generally comparable to manufacturing, and is certainly a business; hence, the gains from this activity should be considered income for the purposes of taxation.<ref name=supreme/>
[[Chief Justice White]], [[Justice McKenna]], and [[Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr.|Justice Holmes]] dissented on the third question.<ref name=supreme/>
==Significance== The case represented one of the Supreme Court's early attempts to define the term “income.”<ref>{{cite web| last =Rosenberg| first =Joshua; Daher, Dominic| title =The Law of Federal Income Taxation| work =Hornbook Series| url =https://books.google.no/books?id=iFvaCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT104&lpg=PT104&dq=Stratton%27s+Independence,+Ltd.+v.+Howbert&source=bl&ots=plswoeGCL9&sig=ZAwMU6xERSdHJPTaaU4T2fMgCoc&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjYsZDwrOHNAhVC1ywKHU6kAC0Q6AEIMDAD#v=onepage&q=Stratton's%20Independence%2C%20Ltd.%20v.%20Howbert&f=false}}</ref>
Justice Pitney's description of income as “the gain derived from capital, from labor, or from both combined” has been widely quoted, as has his comment that “the corporation tax act of 1909 was not intended to be and is not, in any proper sense, an [[income tax]] law.”<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.tax-freedom.com/WhatIsIncome.htm | title=What Is Constitutional Taxable Income ? | work=Tax Freedom | accessdate=July 28, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.tax-freedom.com/WhereDoesIncomeComeFrom.htm | title=WHERE DOES INCOME COME FROM ? | work=Tax Freedom | accessdate=July 28, 2016}}</ref>
The case has been cited (unsuccessfully) in such cases as ''[[Hill v. United States]]'' and ''[[Cameron v. Internal Revenue Service]], in support of the argument that a tax on an individual's income is unconstitutional, even though the decision in Stratton did not rule either corporate or individual income tax unconstitutional.<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iFvaCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT104&lpg=PT104&dq=Stratton%27s+Independence,+Ltd.+v.+Howbert+income&source=bl&ots=plsyn9KEQ9&sig=Xc6B-rGgUe9JopYQ6RQYMC9crVU&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjtmKW_qJfOAhUB04MKHV-eBFQQ6AEIPDAF#v=onepage&q=Stratton's%20Independence%2C%20Ltd.%20v.%20Howbert%20income&f=false | title=The Law of Federal Income Taxation | publisher=Hornbook | author=Rosenberg, Joshua; Daher, Dominic | year=2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bLxBAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA159&lpg=PA159&dq=Stratton%27s+Independence,+Ltd.+v.+Howbert+income&source=bl&ots=TU41Zz_VYP&sig=0NR2DknaS7l8GzYgUvYk94mcemQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjtmKW_qJfOAhUB04MKHV-eBFQQ6AEIRjAH#v=onepage&q=Stratton's%20Independence%2C%20Ltd.%20v.%20Howbert%20income&f=false | title=Federal Income Tax Laws Correlated and Annotated | publisher=John Byrne & Company}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *{{caselaw source | case = ''Stratton's Independence, Ltd. v. Howbert'', {{ussc|231|399|1913|el=no}} | courtlistener =https://www.courtlistener.com/opinion/98014/strattons-independence-ltd-v-howbert/ | findlaw = https://caselaw.findlaw.com/us-supreme-court/231/399.html | googlescholar = https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=11971357151204259952 | justia =https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/231/399/ | loc =http://cdn.loc.gov/service/ll/usrep/usrep231/usrep231399/usrep231399.pdf | openjurist =https://openjurist.org/231/us/399 }}

{{For|other people named William J. Dyer|William Dyer (disambiguation){{!}}William Dyer}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2017}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=January 2017}} '''William John Dyer''' (1830 – 12 July 1909) was a New Zealand businessman and politician.<ref name="dyer">{{Cite web|url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/OW18980331.2.183?query=dyer|title=Biographical Notes of Settlers of the First Decade.|work=[[Otago Witness]]|date=30 March 1898|accessdate=15 January 2017|issue=2300}}</ref><ref name="1859 by-election">{{cite news|url= http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/OW18590115.2.13|work=[[Otago Witness]] |page=5 |issue=372 |date=15 January 1859|accessdate=19 December 2016 |title=Election of a Member for the House of Representatives}}</ref><ref name="1860-election">{{Cite web|url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/OW18601229.2.13|title=Local Intelligence |work=[[Otago Witness]]|date=29 December 1860|accessdate=14 January 2017|issue=474}}</ref> Born in London, his family moved to Sydney when he was a child. He ran a trading business between Sydney, New Zealand and the Pacific Islands, and moved to New Zealand in 1857. He lived at different times in Dunedin and Milton and entered politics, contesting a number of elections and representing the Tokomairaro electorate in the provincial council.
==Personal life==
Dyer was born in London in 1830, but moved to [[Sydney]] in 1839.<ref name="dyer" /> In Sydney, he had two sons, including Frederick James Dyer.<ref>{{cite book |title=The Cyclopedia of New Zealand : Otago & Southland Provincial Districts |year=1905 |url=http://nzetc.victoria.ac.nz//tm/scholarly/tei-Cyc04Cycl-t1-body1-d7-d78-d5.html |publisher=[[The Cyclopedia of New Zealand]] |author=Cyclopedia Company Limited |accessdate= 30 January 2017 |location=Christchurch |chapter=Dyer, Frederick James}}</ref> He moved to New Zealand in 1857. His wife, Emma, died in [[Dunedin]] on 18 September 1858 at age 27.<ref>{{cite news |title=Deaths |url= https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/OW18580925.2.7?query=w.%20j.%20dyer |accessdate=15 January 2017|work=[[Otago Witness]] |issue=356 |date=25 September 1858 |page=5}}</ref> On 21 April 1860, Dyer married Annie Maria Redmayne at the Episcopal Church in Dunedin.<ref>{{cite news |title=Marriage |url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/OW18600428.2.10 |accessdate=16 January 2017 |work=[[Otago Witness]] |issue=439 |date=28 April 1860 |page=5}}</ref> Their first-born son, Ernest Victor, died on 16 February 1861, aged 24 days.<ref name="w. j. dyer">{{cite news |title=Deaths |url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/OW18610223.2.12?query=w.%20j.%20dyer |accessdate=16 January 2017 |work=[[Otago Witness]] |issue=482 |date=23 February 1861 |page=4}}</ref> They had a daughter on 6 January 1864,<ref>{{cite news |title=Births |url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/ODT18640108.2.8?query=w.%20j.%20dyer |accessdate=17 January 2017 |work=[[Otago Daily Times]] |issue=642 |date=8 January 1864 |page=4}}</ref> a son on 30 September 1865,<ref>{{cite news |title=Births |url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/BH18651005.2.10?query=w.%20j.%20dyer |accessdate=19 January 2017 |work=Bruce Herald |volume=III |issue=78 |date=5 October 1865 |page=5}}</ref> and a further son in 1866.<ref>{{cite book |title=The Cyclopedia of New Zealand : Otago & Southland Provincial Districts |year=1905 |url=http://nzetc.victoria.ac.nz//tm/scholarly/tei-Cyc04Cycl-t1-body1-d6-d2-d43.html#t1-body1-d6-d2-d43-d9 |publisher=[[The Cyclopedia of New Zealand]] |author=Cyclopedia Company Limited |accessdate= 30 January 2017 |location=Christchurch |chapter=Blacksmiths, Iron Founders, Etc}}</ref>
==Business career== From Sydney, Dyer traded with New Zealand and the Pacific Islands. When he resided in New Zealand, he was in business in [[Otago]], firstly in Dunedin and later in [[Milton, New Zealand|Milton]] (then known as Tokomairaro). During the [[Otago Gold Rush]], he had a ferry at the [[Taieri River]] at [[Henley, New Zealand|Henley]].<ref name="dyer" /><ref>{{cite news|title=Personal|url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/ODT19090713.2.60?query=dyer%20death|accessdate=15 January 2017 |work=[[Otago Daily Times]] |issue=14574 |date=13 July 1909 |page=6}}</ref> He lost a number of buildings in a fire in January 1871.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bruce Herald|url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/BH18710125.2.13 |accessdate=17 January 2017 |work=Bruce Herald |volume=VI |issue=352 |date=25 January 1871 |page=5}}</ref>
==Political career== Dyer was a candidate in the [[Town of Dunedin by-election, 1859|1859 Town of Dunedin by-election]] against [[James Macandrew]] and [[James Gordon Stuart Grant]]. However, he did not participate in the poll that occurred after Grant challenged Macandrew.<ref name="1859 by-election" /> He contested the [[New Zealand general election, 1860–61|1860 election]] in the {{NZ electorate link|Town of Dunedin}} electorate, losing to [[Thomas Dick (politician)|Thomas Dick]] and [[Edward McGlashan]].<ref name="1860-election" /> He was one of four candidates in the {{NZ election link|1871}} in the {{NZ electorate link|Bruce}} electorate and came second, beaten by [[William Archibald Murray]].<ref name="1871-election">{{cite news|title=Election for Bruce |url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/BH18710201.2.19 |accessdate=16 January 2017 |work=Bruce Herald |volume=VI |issue=353 |date=1 February 1871 |page=5}}</ref> Dyer also was a candidate in the [[Bruce by-election, April 1865|April 1865 Bruce by-election]], getting defeated by [[Arthur John Burns]].<ref name="1865 by-election">{{cite news |url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/BH18650413.2.12|title=Bruce Election |work=Bruce Herald |date=13 April 1865 |accessdate=17 January 2017|volume=II |issue=53|page=}}</ref><ref name="Bruce election">{{Cite news|url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/OW18650415.2.31?query=bruce%20dyer|title=Bruce Election|work=[[Otago Witness]]|issue=698|date=15 April 1865|accessdate=3 February 2017|page=11}}</ref><ref name="Bruce election2">{{Cite news|url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/ODT18650414.2.16?query=the%20election%20for%20bruce|title=Bruce Election|work=[[Otago Daily Times]]|date=14 April 1865|accessdate=3 February 2017|issue=1035|page=6}}</ref> He was also discussed as a candidate in the [[Bruce by-election, July 1865|July 1865 Bruce by-election]], but eventually decided not to stand.<ref name="nomination meeting">{{cite news |title=Tokomairiro |url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/ODT18650714.2.16?query=w.%20j.%20dyer |accessdate=19 January 2017 |work=[[Otago Daily Times]] |issue=1112 |date=14 July 1865 |page=5}}</ref><ref name="July 1865 by-election">{{cite news |url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/ODT18650801.2.15 |title=Bruce Election |work=[[Otago Daily Times]] |date=1 August 1865 |accessdate=20 January 2017 |issue=1127 |page=5}}</ref>
Dyer was several times [[Mayor of Milton]] and a member of the Otago Provincial Council.<ref name="dyer" /><ref name="Scholefield 1950" /> He stood in the Waihola electorate for the [[Otago Provincial Council]] in May 1863<ref name="Scholefield 1950" /> and was defeated by Alexander Mollison by a single vote.<ref>{{cite news |title=Tokomairaro |url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/ODT18630616.2.19?query=w.%20j.%20dyer |accessdate=17 January 2017 |work=[[Otago Daily Times]] |issue=464 |date=16 June 1863 |page=6}}</ref> When [[John Lillie Gillies]] resigned from the Tokomairaro electorate (i.e. the area around Milton) of the Otago Provincial Council, Dyer contested the election against Thomas Murray and was successful.<ref>{{cite news |title=The Otago Daily Times |url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/ODT18640830.2.13?query=w.%20j.%20dyer |accessdate=17 January 2017 |work=[[Otago Daily Times]] |issue=839 |date=30 August 1864 |page=4}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Tokomairiro election |url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/ODT18640905.2.24 |accessdate=17 January 2017 |work=[[Otago Daily Times]] |issue=843 |date=5 September 1864 |page=5}}</ref> He represented the Tokomairaro electorate from 3 September 1864 to 28 July 1866,<ref name="Scholefield 1950">{{cite book | ref = harv |authorlink = Guy Scholefield | last = Scholefield | first= Guy | title = New Zealand Parliamentary Record, 1840–1949 | edition = 3rd | origyear=First published in 1913 | year = 1950 |publisher = Govt. Printer |location = Wellington | page = 224}}</ref> when he resigned.<ref>{{cite news |title=Tokomairiro |url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/OW18660818.2.14?query=w.%20j.%20dyer |accessdate=19 January 2017 |work=[[Otago Witness]] |issue=768 |date=18 August 1866 |page=9}}</ref>
==Later life== [[File:Queen's Hotel, Oamaru 586.jpg|thumb|Dyer died at his son-in-law's Queen's Hotel in [[Oamaru]]]] Dyer moved to Dunedin in his later life and lived in Cumberland Street (now part of [[New Zealand State Highway 1|State Highway 1]]). On 12 July 1909, he died suddenly during a stay at his son in law's Queen's Hotel in [[Oamaru]].<ref name="OM death">{{cite news |title=Death |url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/OAM19090713.2.14?query=dyer%20william%20john |accessdate=15 January 2017 |work=[[The Oamaru Mail]] |volume=XXXVI |issue=10198 |date=13 July 1909 |page=2}}</ref> He was buried at Oamaru Cemetery.<ref name="OM death" />
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
